item.title: Watching o3 guess a photo's location is surreal, dystopian and wildly entertaining
item.description: Watching OpenAI's new o3 model guess where a photo was taken is one of those moments where decades of science fiction suddenly come to life. It's a cross between the Enhance Button and Omniscient Database TV Tropes. The process is simple. Snap a photograph of somewhere, ideally without putting any obvious landmarks in there. item.title: Backfill your blog
item.description:
Fun fact: there's no rule that says you can't create a new blog today and backfill (and backdate) it with your writing from other platforms or sources, even going back many years. I'd love to see more people do this! (Inspired by this tweet by John F. Wu introducing his new blog. I did this myself when I relaunched this blog back in 2017.)
Tags: blogging

item.title: llm-fragment-symbex
item.description: llm-fragment-symbex I released a new LLM fragment loader plugin that builds on top of my Symbex project. Symbex is a CLI tool I wrote that can run against a folder full of Python code and output functions, classes, methods or just their docstrings and signatures, using the Python AST module to parse the code. llm-fragments-symbex brings that ability directly to LLM. item.title: Grumpy morning thoughts
item.description: I earn 5-10X what I did when I lived in the UK, but my quality of life is markedly worse. For a lot of people, the idea of prosperity boils down to, ‚ÄúI can buy what I want,‚Äù not, ‚ÄúI can live how I want.‚Äù The latter is the one that matters: that‚Äôs what freedom actually is. item.title: A trick to feel less like cheating when you use LLMs
item.description: An underestimated challenge in making productive use of LLMs is that it can feel like cheating. One trick I've found that helps is to make sure that I am putting in way more text than the LLM is spitting out . This goes for code: I'll pipe in a previous project for it to modify, or ask it to combine two, or paste in my research notes. It also goes for writing. I hardly ever publish material

item.title: A5
item.description:
A5 A5 is a new "global, equal-area, millimeter-accurate geospatial index" by Felix Palmer:
It is the pentagonal equivalent of other DGGSs, like S2 or H3, but with higher accuracy and lower distortion.
